The Infinite Scroll

When I worked with @af_design, we often argued the effectiveness of infinite scroll on web sites. Apparently my rants did not persuade him, because this morning he sent me a link to Why Infinite Scroll did not work for Etsy. When I considered dismissing the article, our other UX colleague @scholfieldesign chimed in. So what’s this about?

Etsy did no research and assumed their users would benefit from infinite scroll. Right on! Their team implemented the feature only to find that infinite scroll actually decreased user engagement. Dan McKinley explains it here. 

While he does a thorough job explaining why the experiment failed, I still think there other variables are at play (besides potential browser issues).  For example – a user goes 8 “pages” deep, clicks on a product, and then hits the back button. Not likely they’ll return to their previous search page (as you see happen with Twitter and Facebook). Svpply solves this with lightbox product view pages (similar to Twitter profile pages) and then opens the product in a new window. 

Am I so crazy to think people deserve a choice in how their search results get displayed?

Etsy lets you sort how you want

Etsy even lets you view your results how you want.

Why not let users also pick infinite scroll if they want? I mean, you already developed it. I just searched ‘iphone cases’ sorted by most recent giving me 153,445 results. They all look great, but if you think I’m gonna paginate 1,250 pages you’re nuts.
